metadata.product: TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses Square Nerd Eyeglasses Frame

transcript.speaker: **Interviewer
transcript.text: ** David (Corporate Representative)

transcript.speaker: **Interviewee
transcript.text: ** Harper (Customer)

transcript.speaker: **Product
transcript.text: ** TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses Square Nerd Eyeglasses Frame ---

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Good morning, Harper. Thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is David, and I'm with the customer insights team here at TIJN. We really appreciate you agreeing to chat, especially after you left us some feedback on your recent purchase.

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Good morning, David. Yeah, no problem. Happy to. I mean, I spent the time writing the review, might as well talk about it, right?

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Absolutely. And we genuinely value all feedback, especially when it helps us understand where we can improve. Your review was quite detailed, and it raised some significant points for us to consider. To start, could you just tell me a little bit about what initially led you to look for blue light blocking glasses in general?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Oh, well, it was… uh, it was really because of my old job, actually. I was a data analyst for, oh, decades. And you know, that meant being pretty much chained to two large monitors, staring at spreadsheets and dashboards all day, every day. Eight hours minimum. And it really took a toll. My eyes would just feel so gritty and tired by midday, and I’d almost always go home with this nagging tension headache. It just got worse and worse over the years.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That sounds incredibly demanding. So, you were looking for relief from that daily strain. Had you tried anything else before considering blue light glasses? Or was this kind of your first exploration into that specific solution?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Hmm, that’s a good question. Not… not really anything specific for the blue light part. I mean, I’d tried all the usual things, you know, making sure my screen brightness was right, taking breaks, looking away every 20 minutes, lubricating eye drops. All that stuff. It helped a little, maybe, but never really solved the core issue. The headaches and the strain just kept coming back. So, I started hearing about blue light blockers, and it sounded like it could be a real game-changer. Something new, at least.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I see. So you were hopeful this technology could offer a different kind of relief. And what was it specifically about our TIJN glasses, the square nerd frames, that caught your eye among all the options out there? Was it the style, the price, something else?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Mostly a combination, honestly. The "nerd" look appealed to me; I thought it was kind of fun, a bit retro. You know, give me some character while I’m staring at data. And then, frankly, the price was a big factor. It was low enough that I thought, "Well, if they don’t work, it's not a huge loss." That was probably the biggest draw, to be honest. I didn't want to sink a lot of money into something that might not pan out.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That makes perfect sense. It sounds like you were balancing the potential benefits with the risk, given you hadn't tried this kind of solution before. When you first received the package, your review mentioned the simple plastic bag and thin cloth pouch. Could you elaborate a bit on why that stood out to you as a negative first impression?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Well, sure. I mean, for something that's supposed to protect your vision, you'd think it would come in something a bit more substantial, wouldn't you? It just felt… cheap. Like, you know, when you buy something really inexpensive online, and it arrives in just a basic plastic mailer. There was no real protection for the glasses themselves, just that thin fabric pouch. It immediately made me question the overall quality before I even took them out. It wasn’t a deal-breaker, but it definitely lowered my expectations right away.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** I understand. That initial unboxing experience sets a tone, and it sounds like it wasn't the positive impression we aim for. Moving on to the glasses themselves, you mentioned they felt incredibly flimsy. Could you describe that feeling a bit more for me? What made them feel so delicate?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Oh, absolutely. They were so lightweight, it almost felt like they were hollow. And the plastic, it just had that really thin, brittle feel to it. When I opened the arms, there was this distinct creak, every single time. It made me worry they’d just snap in my hands if I wasn't extra careful. Like those toy glasses you get for kids, you know? Not something you'd expect to wear every day for hours.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That creaking sound and the general feel certainly don't inspire confidence. You also went into quite a bit of detail about the physical discomfort once you put them on, particularly the nose pads and the tightness behind your ears. Can you walk me through what that felt like after, say, an hour or two of wear?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Ugh, yeah. The nose pads… if you can even call them that. They weren't separate pads, just molded plastic from the frame itself. And they just dug into the bridge of my nose. After an hour, I’d have these bright red marks, and it would just ache. And the arms, they were just too tight. They pressed right behind my ears, creating these pressure points that became really uncomfortable, really quickly. I tried to bend them a bit, gently, but the plastic felt so stiff and cheap, I was genuinely scared I'd snap them clean off. So, I just… couldn't adjust them. And then, to top it all off, they kept sliding down my nose, so I was constantly pushing them back up. It was just a cycle of irritation.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That sounds incredibly frustrating, having to deal with constant discomfort and adjustments while trying to focus on your screen. You also mentioned trying them for casual phone browsing in the evening, after they didn't work out for your primary work use. Was the experience any different then? Less pressure, perhaps, since it wasn't such an intense environment?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Not really, no. I mean, the *intensity* of the screen focus was different, sure. But the physical discomfort was still there. My nose would still ache, and my ears would still feel those pressure points. It just wasn't pleasant. And even for casual phone use, I still didn’t notice any difference in eye fatigue or, you know, my ability to fall asleep. It just felt like I was wearing plain, slightly yellow-tinted plastic glasses.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That brings me to the blue light blocking functionality itself. You said the effect was "imperceptible" and that the only thing you noticed was an "annoying yellow tint." Could you elaborate on how that tint impacted your screen viewing, especially when you were working on spreadsheets or dashboards?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Oh, it was just… everything looked *off*. When you’re dealing with data, colors are often used for emphasis, or to distinguish categories on a dashboard. And with that yellow tint, everything just looked a little muddy, a little dull. It wasn't vibrant, and it distorted the colors I needed to see accurately. It made it harder to distinguish things, actually. So not only was I not getting the promised blue light blocking, but my visual experience was actively worse.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's a critical piece of feedback, especially for users who rely on color accuracy. And then, you also described a more concerning incident: "a sharp, piercing pain in my left eye." Can you tell me more about that? Had you ever experienced anything like that before, and how did it affect your willingness to continue using the glasses?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** No, never. Absolutely never before. It was really startling. It happened twice, actually. Just this sharp, sudden pain, like a jab, right in my left eye. It lasted for several minutes each time. The first time, I just thought, "Oh, maybe it's just my eye being weird." But when it happened again a day or two later, while I was wearing the glasses, I just immediately took them off. And both times, the pain subsided pretty quickly after I removed them. It scared me enough that I just stopped wearing them for work entirely. I didn’t know if it was a coincidence, or if the lenses were somehow *causing* it, but I wasn't willing to risk it.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's completely understandable, Harper. Any new, sharp pain, especially involving your eyes, is alarming. Thank you for sharing that detail. Given all of these experiences—the discomfort, the lack of perceived benefit, and the alarming eye pain—what was your overall feeling about the value you received for the price you paid, even though the price was low?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Well, as I said in the review, it felt like a complete loss. The low price was initially attractive, right? But if something doesn't work, and it's actively uncomfortable, then any price is too high. It was a waste of money, a waste of my time trying to make them work, and honestly, it just added to my frustration. I’d rather pay more for something that actually delivers on its promise and doesn't cause me physical discomfort. Or pain, for that matter.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Point taken. If you were advising someone else who was experiencing similar eye strain from screen use, what would you tell them about these particular TIJN glasses?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Oh, I'd tell them to absolutely save their money. Don't even bother. I'd say these are poorly constructed, they're painfully uncomfortable, and they simply don't do what they're supposed to. I’d probably suggest they look into other solutions entirely, or at least invest in a much higher-quality pair from a different brand. These are just not worth the hassle or the discomfort.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's very direct feedback, and we appreciate your honesty. If we were to redesign these glasses from the ground up, based on your experience, what would be the top two or three things you'd want us to prioritize for improvement?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Hmm. Okay, well, definitely the comfort. That’s number one. Proper nose pads that don’t dig in, and arms that fit comfortably without squeezing or causing pressure. And adjustability would be great, so people can customize the fit. Secondly, the build quality. They need to feel sturdy, not like they're going to break any second. And a proper, hard case would be nice to protect them. And then, obviously, the core functionality. If they're blue light blockers, they need to actually block blue light effectively, without that annoying yellow tint, and without, you know, causing sharp eye pain. Those would be my top three. Comfort, durability, and actual, effective functionality.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Excellent, clear points, Harper. We'll certainly take those to heart. Just curious, now that you've retired from your data analyst role, are you still spending significant time in front of screens, or has your usage changed?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Oh, I'm definitely still on screens quite a bit, probably not eight hours a day, thank goodness. But I still enjoy catching up on the news, doing some online research for my hobbies, staying in touch with family on video calls, and reading e-books. So, yes, the screen time is still there, just more for personal use now. And I still experience some eye fatigue, so the need for a solution hasn't gone away. It’s just not as acute as it was when I was working.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** So the need is still there, just perhaps a slightly different context. What would it take for you to consider purchasing blue light blocking glasses again in the future, either from TIJN if we made significant changes, or from another brand? What would that ideal experience look like?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** Well, I'd need strong evidence that they actually *work*. Not just, you know, marketing claims, but maybe some independent reviews or testing that backs it up. And they would have to be comfortable, absolutely no question. I’d want to try them on first, if possible, or at least have a very clear return policy. And I'd expect good build quality, something that feels like it’s going to last and withstand daily use. I think I’d be willing to pay more for that, now that I know what can happen with the cheaper options. For me, it would really come down to proven effectiveness and genuine comfort. I don’t need anything fancy, just something that does its job without causing more problems.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** That's a very clear benchmark for us, Harper. Trust, comfort, and efficacy. Before we wrap up, I just have one final question. Thinking about your entire experience with the TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses, from the moment you clicked "buy" to the last time you wore them, on a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is "extremely dissatisfied" and 10 is "extremely satisfied," what overall satisfaction rating would you give your experience?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** (Pauses, a slight sigh) Oh, gosh. That's… that's a tough one. I mean, there was absolutely nothing positive about the experience, apart from the initial hope. So, maybe a… a 1. Honestly. I was extremely dissatisfied. They didn’t help, and they actively caused discomfort and, in one instance, pain. So, yeah, a 1.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** Thank you for that honest rating, Harper. It's incredibly valuable for us to understand the full scope of your experience. We truly appreciate you taking the time today to share your thoughts and provide such detailed feedback. This information will be crucial as we look to improve our products and ensure we're meeting our customers' needs. Is there anything else you'd like to add before we conclude?

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** No, I think I’ve pretty much covered it all. Just hope this helps you guys make something better for other people.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** It absolutely will. Thank you again, Harper. We really appreciate your time.

transcript.speaker: **Harper
transcript.text: ** You’re welcome, David. Have a good day.

transcript.speaker: **David
transcript.text: ** You too. ---
